acf.heading: Get a metoprolol prescription online.
acf.first_paragraph: If you have high blood pressure, getting effective treatment can prevent serious complications.

accordion.accordion_title: What is metoprolol and how does it work?
accordion.accordion_intro: Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that works on blood circulation and flow, as well as the heart. It’s used to treat angina (chest pain) and hypertension (high blood pressure). In hospitals, it’s used to improve your outcome if you’re brought in with a heart attack.

accordion.accordion_title: What is the difference between metoprolol tartrate and metoprolol succinate?
accordion.accordion_intro: Metoprolol tartrate is an immediate-release tablet that must be taken a few times a day. Metoprolol succinate, however, is a timed-release tablet that can be taken once a day. Metoprolol tartrate can be administered in the early stages of a heart attack to improve your outcome, but metoprolol succinate cannot be used in these situations.
accordion.accordion_content: Metoprolol tartrate is also available as an injection for emergency situations. The two versions of the drug are not interchangeable as they have their own dosages and use cases.

accordion.accordion_title: What are metoprolol succinate side effects?
accordion.accordion_intro:
Common side effects of metoprolol succinate are:

  • Drowsiness
  • Dizziness
  • Slow heartbeat
  • Diarrhea
  • Cold hands and feet
accordion.accordion_content: More serious side effects can occur and require immediate attention. If you have blue fingers, toes, or lips, trouble breathing, fainting, worsening heart-related symptoms, swelling ankles/feet, or mood disturbances, see a doctor as soon as possible.

accordion.accordion_title: What are metoprolol tartrate side effects?
accordion.accordion_intro:
Common side effects of metoprolol tartrate are similar to those of metoprolol succinate:

  • Drowsiness
  • Dizziness
  • Slow heartbeat
  • Diarrhea
  • Decreased sexual ability
  • Cold hands and feet
accordion.accordion_content: More serious side effects can occur and require immediate attention. If you have blue fingers, toes, or lips, trouble breathing, fainting, worsening heart-related symptoms, swelling ankles/feet, or mood disturbances, see a doctor as soon as possible.

accordion.accordion_title: Can I mix alcohol and metoprolol?
accordion.accordion_intro: Alcohol can make the dizziness and drowsiness caused by metoprolol worse, so it’s best to avoid drinking while taking metoprolol.
accordion.accordion_content: Tobacco use can exacerbate circulation issues, such as cold hands and feet, and should also be avoided.

accordion.accordion_title: Why do I need to take metoprolol with food?
accordion.accordion_intro: Metoprolol can upset your stomach. Food will help protect your stomach, while making it easier to digest the medication.
accordion.accordion_content: If you have any questions about the medication, you can speak to a doctor on Maple by registering for an account.
